thread.title: Tynemouth constituency General Election results 2017: Full standings, MP and reaction

author: Sonia Sharma
title: Tynemouth constituency General Election results 2017: Full standings, MP and reaction

organizations.name: tynemouth labour - alan campbell alan campbell

text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
This page provides full information about the Tynemouth constituency including candidates standing in the General Election 2017 , history of the seat and 2015 results. 
The interactive tool and information will be updated to show General Election 2017 results once the vote count is declared. 
The polls close at 10pm on Thursday, June 8 and results start being declared around midnight, with Sunderland and Newcastle usually among the first constituencies in the country to announce. 
This page will be updated as soon as the constituency in question has declared. Read More What are the results in my constituency? 
Enter your postcode below to find out more details on your constituency. Which parties and candidates are standing in Tynemouth Labour - Alan Campbell Alan Campbell (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Consett-born Alan studied politics at Lancaster University before qualifying as a teacher and then gaining a postgraduate history degree at the former Newcastle Polytechnic. 
He taught at Whitley Bay High School and Hirst High School in Ashington before he was elected in 1997. 
Since 2010, he has served as Opposition Deputy Whip, after a stint as assistant whip for the Labour Government. 
He has served on Labour MPs’ seaside and coastal towns group, the All Party Small Shops Group and the All Party Fisheries Group. Conservatives - Nick Varley Nick Varley, pictured with Theresa May, is running for the Tories in Tynemouth 
Raised in County Durham, Nick Varley leaded the ground campaign for Vote Leave during the EU referendum. 
A committed Brexiteeer, he says he wants to get the “best deal possible” for Tyneside. 
He wants parents to have more “choice” about where their kids go to school and says he will boost fishing. 
He says: “Only a vote for me will give Theresa May the strongest hand possible in the Brexit negotiations. She will get a good Brexit deal for Tynemouth.” UKIP - Stuart Houghton Tynemouth's UKIP candidate is Stuart Houghton 
Stuart Houghton is the UKIP candidate for Tynemouth. 
He stood in May’s mayoral elections, where he took 6.1% of the votes. 
Born and raised in the North Tyneside borough, he lives in Monkseaton and teaches psychology. He has also lectured at degree level. 
A Brexiteer, he has previously said he wants to help the fishing industry take advantage of leaving the European Union. Liberal Democrats - John Appleby John Appleby, Liberal Democrat candidate for Tynemouth 
Whitley Bay man John is head of mechanical engineering at Newcastle University and teaches maths. 
He has served as a councillor, school governor, union branch president and on church committees. 
John brands himself as a “pragmatist”, who aims to balance well-being with efficiency and acting in everybody’s interest. 
He wants to see increased cooperation in the UK and with Europe through communication and trade. 
On Brexit, he wants further debate before the final deal to leave the European Union is agreed on by MPs. Green Party - Julia Erskine Green Party candidate for Tynemouth, Julia Erskine 
Self-employed dogn walker Julia has been supporting the Green Party since the 1980s, when she was involved with the Newcastle branch. She joined the North Tyneside Green party in 2007 and has lived in Whitley Bay for 12 years. Julia stood in North Tyneside in 2007 and 2015. 
She says: “I have always believed the Green Party to be the only real alternative to the others, and so much of it just makes sense to me that I’ve never wanted to vote for anything else. That is why I do this - to give myself and others the choice to vote Green, and to bring about real, sustainable change.” Independent - “Anthony the Durham Cobbler” Read More
